Note: Principal responsibility for protecting the statute of limitations on Collection cases rests with the Collection function. However, Appeals employees the duty to verify the statute on Collection cases in their inventories to ensure the statute is suspended, when applicable, or to note short statute cases. Since the principal responsibility for the Collection Statute Date (CSED) rests with the Collection function, Appeals has no to prepare and submit a barred statute report if the CSED is determined to be barred. ) All references to Team Managers in this IRM section include Appeals Team Managers and Processing Team Managers (
) All references to Area Directors in this IRM section includes Director, Operations and Director, International Operations. (
) All references to Area Managers in this IRM section refer to Campus and Field Managers under the Director, Account and Processing Support (APS). (

) A barred deficiency is one which can’t be legally assessed because the pre- scribed period for assessment has expired for one or more periods after assigned for examination or Appeals consideration. (
) The term “barred deficiency” includes cases involving restricted interest even though, as a result of the application of net operating loss carrybacks, there no deficiency or overassessment. (
) A statute expiration report is not necessary when Compliance initiates an amination on a barred year. The case should be returned to Compliance and jurisdiction released. (

) A statute expiration report is not required for a return assigned for after the three-year period has expired even though a deficiency was under one of the exceptions to the regular period, e.g., fraud, IRC
(c), it is subsequently determined that such exception does not apply. Such are also not required for returns held solely for reference purposes. Internal Revenue Manual
Appeals Statute (
) If the deficiencies are recovered due to imposition of the fraud penalty, tion of IRC

(c), or for similar reasons, no report is required because deficiencies may be assessed. The report is not required at the time the case is received by an Appeals Office if the return is open under any of the excep- tions to the regular period of limitations. However, in such a case if Appeals later determines that the regular statutory period of limitations applies but the tax cannot be assessed, the deficiency is considered barred at that time and report may be required. See examples below. The report is prepared whether the case was closed in non-docketed status, docketed status, or by decision the United States Tax Court. (
) In cases described in (

) above requiring a statute expiration report where reasons for allowing the period of limitations for assessments to expire do not appear in the administrative file, Appeals will request such information from appropriate Compliance field official when preparing the report. A copy of the report is sent by the Area Director to the appropriate Compliance field official. The items on Form
relating to corrective action taken or recommended and disciplinary action taken, if any, are not to be filled in by Appeals. (

In cases not Statute Expiration factors of uncertainty as to probability of assessment, such as possible tion of fraud penalty, the reports will be prepared immediately upon that the statutory period expired without assessment. In cases where a mination cannot be made at time of discovery, for example, where the penalty may be asserted, the reports are submitted when it is finally mined that the assessment will not be made because of the expiration of statutory period. (11-06-2013) Potentially Barred Statutes
A statute is considered “potentially barred” until sufficient research of the facts allows a determination whether it is an actual barred statute or not.
Regardless of the group or team responsible for the potentially barred statute, the employee or team manager of the employee who discovered the potentially
Appeals Statute barred statute will prepare a preliminary Form
and the team manager forward it to the Area Director or Area Manager within ten (
) business from the date of discovery. (

) The case with the potentially barred statute should remain on the Appeals Centralized Database System (ACDS) until a final decision is made as to whether the statute is actually barred or until the final Form
has been submitted. If the responsibility for the final Form

) If unable to determine or in doubt if the assessment can be made and the revenue protected: a. send an expedited request to local Counsel to review and provide guidance. b. include as much factual data as possible about the taxpayer in (including transcripts, TXMOD and/or CFOL information) with the submitted to Counsel for opinion. 8.21.7.7.1 (11-06-2013) Final Barred Statute Report
a. The team manager will also sign and date the preliminary Form
in Part B, in the block labeled “First-Level Manager” and forward it to their Area Director or Area Manager within ten (

) business days from the date of discovery. b. Since the final decision has been made that a barred statute has occurred, the case can be closed off of ACDS and the taxpayer can be notified. However, the administrative file should be retained until a copy of the approved final report is returned.
c. APS will close the case using closing code
or

will be used when the case is closed as a premature referral jurisdiction is released. Generally, closing code

YYMM (Calendar Year and Month of Discovery) and a brief identification of the attachment, (Example- DFO Memo, Counsel Memo, Discipline, etc.) ” The final barred statute report should include an explanation of the recom- mended disciplinary action against each employee deemed responsible. ) When Appeals makes a preliminary determination that Compliance is respon- sible for the potentially barred statute, the employee that discovered the potentially barred statute will immediately notify their team manager and prepare a preliminary Form
is (
) The team manager will forward the preliminary Form
to the Area or Area Manager within ten (

) business days from the date of discovery. If the Area Director concurs that Compliance appears to be responsible, the Director will send his or her concurrence to the Appeals team manager by e-mail. (

) Upon receipt of the Area Director’s concurrence, the Appeals team manager will inform the manager of the responsible group in Compliance and obtain their concurrence. Only expired statutes meeting the specific criteria for each Compliance operating division will be forwarded to the operating division re- sponsible for the expired statute. Note: IRM

and all attachments to the Executive Assistant to the Chief of Appeals for recommendation. (
) During this process, jurisdiction of the case will remain in Appeals. (
) If the Chief Appeals determines that Appeals is responsible for the barred statute, then the final Form
procedures at IRM
should be followed. (

) If the Chief Appeals determines that Compliance is responsible for the barred statute, then the Directors, Field Operations, Director, Specialty tions, Director, Campus Operations or the Director, Policy, Quality and Case Support will take the following actions:
The ATM or PTM will complete Form
, Part A accompanied by a narrative supporting the preliminary determination and a time-line of events leading to the barring of the statute.
The ATM or PTM will forward Form
and supporting documentation the Area Director or Area Manager.

and documentation. If the package is correct and complete, the Area Director or Area Manager will forward it to the Directors, Field Operations, Specialty Operations, Director, Campus Operations or Director, APS ten (

8.21 Appeals Statute Responsibility
) Area Directors and Area Managers must ensure that proposed disciplinary actions meet the criteria in IRM
, Internal Revenue Service Guide Penalty Determinations. (

) When more than one employee is found to have contributed to a statute barring, the respective senior managers should make every effort to reach agreement on the proposed discipline for all employees involved. (

) As a general rule, all employees who contributed in any way to a barred statute may be subject to some form of disciplinary action. However the the Level of pline will not necessarily be the same for all involved employees. for a (

) When determining the level of disciplinary action, the following facts should Statute considered individually for each employee: a. Severity of the employee’s error b. Point in time during the processing of the case the employee made the error c. Number and position of other employees who handled the case subse- quent to the employee
Severity of the employee’s error Point in time during the processing of the case the employee made the error Number and position of other employees who handled the case subse
quent to the employee

For Example: The severity of an error made by APS when the case is established, diminishes if the error goes undetected after the case is subsequently handled by management and higher-graded technical employees. Ideally, these type errors should be detected by the Appeals Team Manager when the case is received for assignment and/or when the higher-graded technical employee reviews the case upon assignment. Thus, the APS employee may not be totally relieved of responsi- bility but their disciplinary action will not equal that imposed on the technical employee and the technical employee’s manager who subsequently handled the case if the error goes undetected until later in the Appeals process.
) Because each case is different, the level of responsibility will be determined a case-by-case basis. (

) In most barred statute cases, multiple employees contribute to the situations that result in a barred statute. Therefore, all factors must be considered when determining the degree of responsibility for each. (
) Even though an employee has jurisdiction of a case on ACDS, another employee may have actual possession and virtual control over the movement of that case. (
) The employee with jurisdiction of the case must continue to take every possible action to get the employee with possession and control of movement to act. (
) All actions taken by the employee with jurisdiction should be clearly detailed in the Case Activity Record (CAR) so that there is documentation to support the attempts made. (

) When an employee with possession and control of the movement of a case fails to adhere to the employee with jurisdiction’s requests to handle the case in a timely manner in order to prevent a barred statute, the employee with session and control of the movement may be held fully responsible for the barred statute.

) It is possible for an Appeals employee and a Compliance employee to responsibility for a barred statute. When this occurs, the impacted Appeals Shared manager must prepare the preliminary and final reports for Appeals. (

) The fact that Compliance is involved does not change the requirement that Appeals manager follow all the procedures for preparing and submitting a barred statute report described in this IRM section. (

Written notification of the taxpayer will be a personal letter similar to Pattern Letter P-427 (IRM 4.2.1-1 , General Examination Information) and send an

a. The report is a copy of the Examination report which the taxpayer protested or a revision of the Examination report based upon Appeals de- termination. b. The report should reflect a deficiency resulting from issues that have been considered by Appeals. The taxpayer does not need to agree to the ad- justments since Pattern Letter P-
advises the taxpayer that “the report reflects our determination”. Adjustments that give the taxpayer a beneficial “double deduction” are prohibited as discussed in IRC Treasury
, e.g., capitalizing an item previously expensed and allowing a ciation deduction in subsequent years. IRC

(a) provides that the term “overpayment” includes: Any payment of any Internal Revenue tax which is assessed or collected after the expiration of the period of limitation ap- plicable. It will generally be possible for the taxpayer to file a timely claim within two years and have any payment refunded. This permits a double deduction if any report includes any issues that involve subsequent returns. c. The purpose of the report is to assist the taxpayer in filing subsequent returns and to furnish the amount of the deficiency if the taxpayer elects make voluntary payment. d. The report will clearly show that the statute has expired and the taxpayer is under no legal obligation to pay the deficiency shown. , Special Handling Notice, that payment from the taxpayer was voluntarily received after statute expiration. Submit the case for normal processing. b. If the taxpayer does make payment, a personal letter similar to Pattern Letter P-

, General Examination Information) should be written acknowledging receipt of the payment and expressing tion. (see IRM
, General Examination Information) should be issued to the taxpayer. Pattern Letter P-

explains that the examination has been discontinued because the statutory period the Service can legally issue a refund or assess and enforce collection of amounts due has expired. In multi-year and related examinations, it is not necessary to separately process the year in which the statute expired. The return can follow the case file through the normal examination process.
